message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Combination oral contraceptive pills are contraindicated in breastfeeding women due to the risk of decreased milk production and potential transfer of hormones to the infant. None of the other options listed are absolute contraindications, though caution may be needed with elevated blood pressure and a history of epilepsy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Breastfeeding is an absolute contraindication for combination oral contraceptive pills due to potential transfer of hormones to the infant through breast milk. The other options may require caution and consideration, but are not absolute contraindications.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Breastfeeding is an absolute contraindication for combination oral contraceptive pills due to the increased risk of thromboembolism. History of epilepsy, elevated blood pressure, and mild liver fibrosis are not absolute contraindications, but they may require careful consideration and monitoring while on the medication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Combination oral contraceptive pills have an absolute contraindication in patients who are breastfeeding, as they can decrease milk production and alter the composition of breast milk. None of the other options listed are absolute contraindications, although elevated blood pressure may increase the risk of cardiovascular events.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only breastfeeding is an absolute contraindication to using combination oral contraceptive pills. This is because estrogen in the pill can reduce milk production and also increase the risk of clotting in lactating women. It is important to note that other factors such as the patient’s history of migraines with aura and elevated blood pressure may also make combination oral contraceptive pills a less ideal choice and must be taken into consideration.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. While breastfeeding itself is not a contraindication to starting combination oral contraceptive pills, the patient's desire for exclusive breastfeeding is. Combination oral contraceptive pills can decrease milk production and alter the composition of breast milk. Therefore, it is an absolute contraindication for the patient who is exclusively breastfeeding. None of the other options listed are absolute contraindications to starting combination oral contraceptive pills, but they may warrant closer monitoring or consideration of alternative methods.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Combination oral contraceptive pills are contraindicated in patients who are breastfeeding because it can decrease breast milk production and alter the composition of breast milk. The patient's history of epilepsy, mild liver fibrosis, and elevated blood pressure are not absolute contraindications to starting combination oral contraceptive pills, but they may require careful monitoring.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Combination oral contraceptive pills are contraindicated in breastfeeding mothers due to the risk of decreasing milk supply. History of epilepsy, elevated blood pressure, and mild liver fibrosis are relative contraindications but not absolute contraindications. It is still important to consider the patient’s medical history and discuss the potential risks and benefits of the contraceptive method.

We refer to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidelines for contraception use. Breastfeeding is an absolute contraindication to start the patient on combination oral contraceptive pills because they can decrease milk production and transfer to breast milk. History of epilepsy, elevated blood pressure, and mild liver fibrosis are not absolute contraindications, but caution should be taken and alternative methods or lower dose pills may be considered.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Breastfeeding is an absolute contraindication to start combination oral contraceptive pills due to the potential for decreased milk production and transfer of hormones to the baby. While the patient has a history of epilepsy and abnormal liver function with mild fibrosis, these are not absolute contraindications to combination oral contraceptive pills. Elevated blood pressure is a relative contraindication and should be monitored closely.
